channel.title: Contents on Super.NET Blog, Dawg
channel.description: Recent content in Contents on Super.NET Blog, Dawg

item.title: MSFT vs MS
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)

item.title: Hello World: Welcome to Super.NET Blog, Dawg
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: Welcome to the Super.NET Blog, Dawg! Here, you will find supplemental resources for the Super.NET main site, as well as the archive for the now-retired “Developers.win!” Built with Hugo I have been spending some time with Hugo in designing this site, and I have been nothing short of being completely and utterly impressed.

item.title: Who is Agent Smith?
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: While running Developers Win! last year I’d like to say, I made contact with a developer in the comments of one of my posts that I would classify is part of the dark matter, and have assigned the name Agent Smith.

item.title: Investigating Weird Result Times in Benchmark.NET
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: TL;DR I’ve spent the past year or so by way of 100 collective hours wrestling with a JIT-related code alignment issue which is now being tracked on both the Benchmark.

item.title: Thoughts on //build 2018 and Why ScottGu Should be MSFT CEO
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: Brushing Off the Dust Alright, a lot has been happening in the world lately and I have felt the need to brush off this blog and share some thoughts of mine that have collected over the past few months and weeks.

item.title: Where Are the Vote Reports?
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: You’ve probably noticed that the vote reports have stopped here on Developers.win. Unless of course you don’t care about them, then you haven’t noticed them at all. ðŸ™‚ These of course were a side project of mine based on the Xaml-console based application that ran on a weekly basis, tallying the latest vote totals from numerous Microsoft UserVoice forums.

item.title: Weekly Vote Report for Friday, February 17, 2017
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: This week marks a special note as we have now crossed into 45,000 total votes asking for a ubiquitous .NET client application development model. Additionally, worth of note, Miguel de Icaza recently remarked on Mono’s port to WebAssembly, which would officially enable this scenario.

item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: Awwww jyea! Today marks the big 3-0-0-0 mark for the premiere featured vote here on Developers Win! The report below (generated earlier this morning) shows it at 2,999. However, if you check it out now it is over the 3k mark.

item.title: Weekly Vote Report for Friday, April 8, 2016
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: We are still clipping along at just over 100 votes for the past week towards the premiere vote featured here on Developers.win. I personally am amazed that this idea still continues to achieve such a great rate of success after six months of existence.

item.title: Speak Up
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: Yesterday marked the 6th month mark of the premiere vote of Developers.win. In this time, over 2700 votes have been accounted towards the idea of a ubiquitous .NET client application development model.

item.title: Weekly Vote Report for Friday, April 1, 2016
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: Exciting news this week. With the announcements at //build, we are now shaping up towards a truly ubiquitous .NET development model. The Xamarin in Visual Studio announcement makes this idea a closer reality.

item.title: Exploring Microsoftâ€™s Xamarin Acquisition with 7 Simple Graphics
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: TL;DR: Vote! The purpose of this article is to build consensus around a ubiquitous .NET client application development model. With Xamarin’s acquisition yesterday, this gets us closer, but not quite there.

item.title: For Your Review: We Are Under Review!
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: Wat Is It? YesterdayÂ at around 3:30 PM PT/ 6:30 PM ET, the Visual Studio team marked the premiere idea that this site was built around,Â Create a Ubiquitous .

item.title: How NodeJS Is Dominating .NET in 3 Easy Charts
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: Wat Now? OK I have to admit my title to this article is my first attempt at click bait. Hey, I’m learning my new toy here, what can I say?

item.title: Is the Tide Turning on project.json?
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: Wat Want? I am not exactly aÂ fan of the new project.json initiative underway betweenÂ the Visual Studio and ASP.NET Core rewrite. In fact, I have been so concerned withÂ it that I have created a vote to change this very issueÂ along withÂ other latent misgivings in the Visual Studio project system.

item.title: The .NET Exodus to NodeJS: Sound Off
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: What Want? Are you a NodeJS developer? More importantly, are you a former or current .NET developer? Are you a .NET developer thinking of making the switch to NodeJS?

item.title: The Great .NET Client Divide: A Simple Example (Hopefully)
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: TL;DR: Vote! I have been getting some good feedback on writing lengthy blog articles. Right right. I try to be aware and respectful of your time. And mine, too. At the end of the day I am just some random developer that you don’t know who happens to put their thoughts on the web — and I try to keep that in mind.

item.title: Weekly Vote Report for Friday, February 5, 2016
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: Two new votes have been added for this week: Run Xaml / C# (like Silverlight) Applications Inside, without Plug-in and Negotiate with Other Major Browsers Manufacturers Over a Common IL. In all, these votes bring us up to 1,000 votes away from 25,000 total votes asking for a ubiquitous .

item.title: Improving Microsoft Developer Engagement with Disqus
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: TL;DR: VOTE! This post exists to build consensus in the Microsoft developer community to help improve the blogging systems used in various Microsoft properties by using Disqus. Show your support by voting for this idea here for Visual Studio and Visual Studio Team Services (MSDN):

item.title: Weekly Vote Report for Friday, January 22, 2016
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: Cranking along here. We continue to see good movement with the Ubiquitous .NET vote, having passed 1500 this week. I continue to be humbled and appreciative for all the support. Thank you so much to all who have contributed their votes!

item.description: Back again to a steady schedule this week. As always, if you feel there is a vote that should be included in this list, please let us know in the comments.

item.title: Weekly Vote Report for Friday, January 1, 2016
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: Happy New Year! We here at Developers Win wish you the best and most productive year yet in 2016. We start this year out with a new Weekly Report, delivered on time early Friday morning.

item.title: Weekly Vote Report for Saturday, December 26, 2015
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: Well, another week and another day late. This time it was due to a logistical issue rather than a technical one, that being a visit by Mr. Santa yesterday for Christmas.

item.title: Weekly Vote Report for Saturday, December 19, 2015
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: Well now, a little late this week due to some technical difficulties. Based on a tip from Sir Eder, the reports now include another vote for One .NET Framework, which would be necessary for a ubiquitous .

item.title: Eight Weeks, 1,000+ Votes, #1 Hottest Vote â€” THANK YOU!!!
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: “Amazing! WOW! Incredible!” Those are a few of the words that sit in my head this morning. When I set out to make this site over sixÂ months ago, I really didn’t have any expectations or know what to expect.

item.title: Hello World! (again)
item.author: run@superdotnet.run (Mike-EEE)
item.description: I am very happy to announce the first posting on this blog! This has been an effort that has taken a few weeks now. As with anything dealing with software, it is never as easy as initially perceived, and has taken much longer than anticipated.
